comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35672655@N00] dunno whos the kid,  but he is immortalized on a glass negative.  There is a great series of photos of the building of the Ultimo Powerhouse (now the Powerhouse Museum) in Photo Investigator.   Electricity needed primarily for the new tramway network and street lighting.  Tramcar House was next door.

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Ultimo depot, was located in Mary Ann St Ultimo. This depot was constructed in the standard design of the day for Tram depots. It was in existence as an operational depot from 1899 to 1953. It provided trams for services on the following lines in conjunction with Fort Macquarie depot Fort Macquarie to Pyrmont, Fort Macquarie to Ryde, Circular Quay to Erskineville, Ryde to Ryde station, Darling St Wharf to Leichhardt, Bridge St City to Central Railway, Darling St Wharf to Canterbury (until 1953) The depot had 12 roads under cover. penultimo.tumblr.com/post/3112990479/tramdays Now under the control of the Powerhouse Museum (formerly MAAS) and the front part of the depot became the first display area for the new museum. The depot is now a storage area for small exhibits and a works area. The museum took over the former tramway powerhouse, which is located immediately behind the depot, and opened in 1988. View today binged.it/RA4hGT

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a very similar (but slightly earlier) photo in this Sydney Mail article about the tramways from April 1898 - news.google.com/newspapers?id=YhFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WpUDA... . The article gives interesting details about the construction of the "car-house" and the tramway.
